Description: Body fragments of Attic black-figured pottery oenochoe, reconstructed; neck, mouth and foot restored. Alternating red and black tongue frieze at top of shoulder, rays at foot; two fragmentary animal friezes separated by a triple dot band between pairs of lines on body; on shoulder, from left, trace of animal, siren to left, sphinx and cock to right; below, bull to left, confronted panther and goat.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The vessel was presumably restored at the British Museum prior to being shipped to Boston.
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 340)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 231, no. 163)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 124 no. 349, pl. XXXVIII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1212)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.6226 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
